awd_titl_txt: DM Genes and Dynamic Specification of Dimorphism
awd_abstract_narration:
Nearly all animal species have two distinct sexes. However, the genetic differences between males and females of a given species are generally very small and sometimes even non-existent. This project will use the nematode C. elegans, a powerful genetic model system, to test the hypothesis that a set of conserved genes (the DMRT genes) acts as a bridge between these minimal genetic sex differences and the changes in developmental and physiological programs that distinguish males and females. It is expected that these genes provide tailored information to individual cells during development, instructing cells to undergo sex-specific processes only at the correct time and in the correct place. 

Understanding how these genes carry out these functions will help reveal the ways in which two distinct sexes can be "encoded" in one genome, a fundamental issue in developmental biology. Moreover, it will provide fundamental insight into the ways in which developmental programs can be fine-tuned to bring about changes in structural appearance and physiological functions. This research will also have important value in training undergraduate and graduate students in cutting-edge molecular genetics, and will make special efforts to involve those from groups traditionally underrepresented in the biological sciences. The research process and its findings will be shared with the community through a variety of outreach mechanisms, including novel uses of social media by student researchers.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview: Most animal species have two sexes that tend to differ in some characteristics. These differences can be morphological (differences in their physical form), physiological (having to do with their internal metabolic functions), and behavioral. The ways in which these differences arise is not well understood. The goal of this project was to better understand, at a cellular level, the molecular-genetic mechanisms that guide cells along different developmental pathways to bring about sexual dimorphisms that arise as animals reach sexual maturity. We focused on a family of genes called DM genes, because these genes are conserved throughout the animal kingdom and have been implicated in the development of several kinds of sexual dimorphisms in widely diverse species. For these studies, we used a tiny roundworm, Caenorhabditis elegans, because powerful genetic tools have been established to study it, and because specific examples of morphological, physical, and behavioral dimorphisms have been previously identified.

Intellectual Merit: This research project made significant contributions to understanding the development of sexual dimorphisms in C. elegans. First, we found that a DM gene called mab-3 is essential for generating an important behavioral difference between the two sexes. By fine-tuning the physiological features of a single class of chemosensory neuron, mab-3 is able to allow these neurons to sensitively detect pheromones in only one sex, while these neurons remain insensitive to pheromones in the other sex. Interestingly, these neurons are also present in sexually immature animals, and do not detect pheromones at this stage. mab-3 is activated in these neurons at the juvenile-to-adult transition, indicating that, at a cellular level, the molecular encoding of biological sex is dynamic, and can change the functional properties of a cell according to an animal?s developmental stage. These results also show that a behavioral dimorphism can arise through altered sensitivity of chemosensory organs that are present in both sexes. Second, these studies contributed to the functional characterization of a new functional RNA called lep-5, which plays an important role in determining the time at which some DM genes are activated. Without this RNA, some DM genes do are not activated at the correct time, causing specific cells to remain arrested in a juvenile state. These findings establish an exciting new link between the developmental timing mechanisms that act in cells and factors that implement their sexual differentiation. Our research findings were disseminated at national conferences and through open-access peer-reviewed publications.

Broader Impacts: This project had important broader impacts in scientific training. Several graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow received state-of-the-art training in genetics and developmental biology, including advanced techniques in microscopy and genetic manipulation. Over 10 undergraduates also played important roles in this project; for most of them, this was their first exposure to a university research laboratory. Many of these students were selected in a competitive program from smaller institutions whose research infrastructure is not as well-developed. Further, students took part in public outreach opportunities including Brain Awareness Week.

Summary: These studies provided important new insights into the molecular-genetic mechanisms that fine-tune animals? morphological, physiological, and behavioral features as they become sexually mature. The findings provide groundwork for future studies to better understand these mechanisms in other systems. This research also provided outstanding training opportunities for undergraduates, graduate students, and a postdoctoral fellow in state-of-the-art molecular genetics and developmental biology.
